content: For some secret reasons of my own I'm trying to understand affine toric varieties. Anyone here know about them?
They're a lot simpler than projective toric varieties, so probably everyone who cares about toric varieties considers them kinda boring.

The basic idea is this. Let Nk\mathbb{N}^kNk be our friend the free commutative monoid on kkk generators. Let SSS be any submonoid of this - it turns out, by the way, that they're all finitely presented. Let C[S]\mathbb{C}[S]C[S] be the free vector space on the underlying set of SSS. This is naturally a commutative algebra - it's the free commutative algebra on the commutative monoid SSS. It's finitely presented so it corresponds to an affine algebraic variety. And such varieties are affine toric varieties.

For example consider the submonoid of N\mathbb{N}N generated by 2,72, 72,7 and 999:

S={0,2,4,6,7,8,9,10,12,14,16,18,20,21,22,24,26,27,28,30,… }S = \{0,2,4,6,7,8,9,10,12,14,16,18,20,21,22,24,26,27,28,30,\dots \}S={0,2,4,6,7,8,9,10,12,14,16,18,20,21,22,24,26,27,28,30,…}
Then we can think of C[S]\mathbb{C}[S]C[S] as the subalgebra of the algebra of complex polynomials in one variable xxx generated by x2,x7x^2, x^7x2,x7 and x9x^9x9.

We can also think of this as the complex algebra generated by X=x2,Y=x7,Z=x9X = x^2, Y = x^7, Z = x^9X=x2,Y=x7,Z=x9 and obeying some relations like XY=ZXY = ZXY=Z and X7=Y2X^7 = Y^2X7=Y2 and X9=Z2X^9 = Z^2X9=Z2... one can work out the relations one needs, but notice they are all of the form "one monomial in X,Y,ZX,Y,ZX,Y,Z equals another monomial". In another approach to affine toric varieties, that becomes the definition: they're affine algebraic varieties that are defined by equations of the form "one monomial equals another monomial".

Ok, I'll throw a random fact at you: The only smooth affine toric varieties are of the form An×(Gm)k\mathbb{A}^n\times(\mathbb{G}_m)^kAn×(Gm​)k. That is Prop. 4.45 of Bruns/Gubeladze: Polytopes, Rings and K-Theory.
(My interest in this fact was that this is an easy starting point for motivic homotopy theory over F1\mathbb{F}_1F1​)

Nice fact! What I'm interested in now is geometric quantization of complex affine toric varieties - or in other words, holomorphic line bundles over such varieties, and their spaces of holomorphic sections. This may seem like an eccentric subject: most people like to study geometric quantization for smooth projective varieties, where you get nice finite-dimensional spaces of sections. And yet it's what I want to know about.

Are there bunches of people who use toric varieties as a way of thinking about algebraic geometry over F1\mathbb{F}_1F1​? I've thought that could make sense, since toric varieties are sort of "algebraic geometry with only multiplication, not addition" - as illustrated in my little spiel about commutative monoids.
I don't even know what geometric quantization means, it sounds eccentric to me either way :innocent:

Toric varieties (or monoid schemes, slightly more generally) are sort of the minimal consensus as to which schemes are defined over F1\mathbb{F}_1F1​. I think really everyone agrees that those should be there - exactly because the affine pieces can be defined without addition, and the glueing maps as well. They are just not enough to say that many interesting things. For example the group scheme GLnGL_nGLn​ is not a toric variety, but by the Tits building philosophy it should be defined over F1\mathbb{F}_1F1​.

The correspondence between toric varieties and F1\mathbb{F}_1F1​-varieties is described in Deitmar's "F1\mathbb{F}_1F1​-schemes and toric varieties". Every complex toric variety is the base change of an F1\mathbb{F}_1F1​-variety to C\mathbb{C}C, and conversely if you take the base change of an F1\mathbb{F}_1F1​-variety to C\mathbb{C}C you get a complex variety with the property that every irreducible component is toric (Theorem 4.1).

Deitmar's F1\mathbb{F}_1F1​-schemes are the analogue of usual schemes, after replacing "commutative ring" by "commutative monoid".
Yes, Deitmar's setting (and equivalently Toën/Vaquié's) captures exactly that minimal consensus.

Something else that I find very interesting about affine toric varieties is that the Quillen–Suslin theorem holds for them. So every vector bundle over an affine toric variety is trivial. I don't think there is a direct proof of this yet, the proof builds on the Quillen–Suslin theorem for affine space.
Ah cool, I didn't know that!

Great, thanks! This is just what I needed to know. This confirms my impression that geometric quantization of affine toric varieties would be considered "dull" by most experts.

(The more usual situation studied is something like the total flag variety G/B of a simple Lie group G, where you get a line bundle for each way of labeling its Dynkin diagram's dots with natural numbers, and only the labeling by all zeros gives a trivial line bundle. The space of holomorphic sections of such a line bundle becomes a finite-dimensional irreducible representation of G, and we get all the irreducible representations this way.)

4.45 doesn't seem to be the right number for that result.

What you quoted is Theorem 4.46 in my copy of the book. I meant the proposition right before:
BrunsGubeladze.png

(an affine monoid is a submonoid of Zn\mathbb{Z}^nZn)
@Peter Arndt It was my understanding that an affine monoid is a finitely generated, cancellative, torsion-free submonoid of Nn\mathbb N^nNn. Is the same term used to mean two different things?

I forgot about the "finitely generated", that condition is necessary - thanks!
Bruns and Gubeladze define an affine monoid to be a finitely generated submonoid of Zn\mathbb{Z}^nZn. That is equivalent to being a finitely generated, cancellative, torsionfree monoid. Note that submonoids of Zn\mathbb{Z}^nZn (hence also of Nn\mathbb{N}^nNn) are always cancellative and torsionfree. Vice versa, a cancellative monoid embeds into its group completion, finite generatedness implies that that is a finitely generated abelian group, and torsionfreeness implies torsionfreeness of that group, so such a monoid is a submonoid of some Zn\mathbb{Z}^nZn.

I don't know if there are other common conventions as to what "affine monoid" means, but if you require that your monoid is a submonoid of Nn\mathbb{N}^nNn, it means that you don't allow any element to have inverses. Then the above proposition would be false: C[Z]=C[x,x−1]\mathbb{C}[\mathbb{Z}]=\mathbb{C}[x,x^{-1}]C[Z]=C[x,x−1] is definitely regular.
Ah yes, I somehow managed to state the two equivalent definitions at the same time!

So are all finitely generated cancellative torsion-free commutative monoids isomorphic to submonoids of Zn\mathbb{Z}^nZn for some finite nnn? Is that the theorem here?

What are necessary and sufficient conditions for a monoid to be isomorphic to a submonoid of Nn\mathbb{N}^nNn? We've just seen a necessary condition is that 0 is the only element with an inverse.
I'm getting really interested in this stuff for certain top-secret reasons.

According to a citation made in @Robin Piedeleu's thesis on page 44, by Theorem 3.11 of "Finitely Generated Commutative Monoids" by Rosales and Garcia-Sanches:
finitely generated submonoids of Nn\mathbb N^nNn, for some nnn, are equivalent to torsion free, cancellative, non-negative, commutative monoids.
Nice! And just to be 100% sure: does "non-negative" mean the only element with an inverse is 0?
Yes
By the way, I think you put "finitely generated" on the wrong side of the equivalence. All submonoids of Nn\mathbb{N}^nNn are finitely generated.
Oh wait, could this be wrong???
I believe that not all submonoids of Nn\mathbb N^nNn are finitely generated because it isn't Noetherian. But I think they are finitely presented.
How could something be finitely presented but not finitely generated? A finite presentation has finitely many generators and finitely many relations?
I think in this case finitely generated means free on finite generators?
Which is not the usual way of using that term
Yikes!!! Who uses "finitely generated" to mean "finitely generated free"? That's evil!
I can't find a copy of this book, which makes it hard to read about affine monoids!

Anyway, it's certainly not true that every submonoid of Nn\mathbb{N}^nNn is finitely generated and free. Consider the submonoid of N\mathbb{N}N consisting of {0,2,3,4,5,… }\{0,2,3,4,5,\dots\}{0,2,3,4,5,…}.

I managed to find a pdf of the book:
Selection_013.png

Okay, I think I understand my confusion. This was helpful...

  1. Every submonoid of N\mathbb{N}N is finitely generated - this is claimed here.

  2. Dickson’s Lemma: Any subset of Nn\mathbb{N}^nNn has a finite set of minimal elements, where we define x≤yx \le yx≤y iff xi≤yix_i \le y_ixi​≤yi​ for all iii.

  3. But apparently not every submonoid of N2\mathbb{N}^2N2 is finitely generated. I think I can see a counterexample in this picture that illustrates Dickson's Lemma: just take {(m,n):mn≥9}\{(m,n) : m n \ge 9 \}{(m,n):mn≥9}.

My problem was that I'd misremembered Dickson's Lemma!

By the way, "finitely generated" has a standard meaning for models of any Lawvere theory: it means being a quotient of a free model on finitely many generators. So, this works for groups, semigroups, monoids, rings, Lie algebras, etc. To tweak this meaning in special cases would be evil. But the pdf Cole just showed gives a definition equivalent to this one, in the special case of monoids.

I am learning about affine monoids partly through Robin's thesis: where he gives a presentation for the prop which is the full subcategory of relations of finitely generated commutative monoids, with objects being affine monoids. I have to shout it out, because it is a very nice read, in my opinion! I hope I didn't state the main result wrong!

Cole Comfort said:

According to a citation made in Robin Piedeleu's thesis on page 44, by Theorem 3.11 of "Finitely Generated Commutative Monoids" by Rosales and Garcia-Sanches:
finitely generated submonoids of Nn\mathbb N^nNn, for some nnn, are equivalent to torsion free, cancellative, non-negative, commutative monoids.

This can't be quite right without something sneaky going on, because not every "torsion free, cancellative, non-negative, commutative monoid" is finitely generated. Take the free commutative monoid on a countable infinity of generators, for example.

Yes, the condition of being finitely-generated is also on the other side of the statement if I remember correctly: finitely-generated submonoids of Nd\mathbb{N}^dNd are equivalent to finitely-generated, torsion-free, cancellative, non-negative, and commutative monoids!
(I think the Rosales and Garcia-Sanchez text is only about finitely-generated commutative monoids, but I don't recall that they use "finitely-generated" in a non-standard sense...)
Indeed, you need "finitely generated" on both sides. As you do in the Zd\mathbb{Z}^dZd-case whose proof I sketched above.

And there really are non-finitely generated submonoids of Nd\mathbb{N}^dNd. Consider for example the submonoid of N2\mathbb{N}^2N2 generated by {(1,0),(1,1),(1,2),(1,3),(1,4),(1,5),...}={1}×N\{ (1,0),(1,1), (1,2), (1,3), (1,4), (1,5), ...\} = \{1\}\times \mathbb{N}{(1,0),(1,1),(1,2),(1,3),(1,4),(1,5),...}={1}×N.
